messages.content: What are the four sides of the mind?

The four sides are your ego, subconscious, unconscious, and superego. Your test result - like INTP - is just your ego. That's 25% of who you are. The other three sides are complete personality types living in your head. So an INTP has an ENTJ unconscious, ESFJ subconscious, and ISFP superego. You're literally four people in one.
Why do MBTI tests feel so limiting?

Because they only measure your ego - one side of your mind. People feel boxed in because they notice themselves being extroverted sometimes when they tested introverted, or vice versa. That's not you switching types. That's you accessing your subconscious or unconscious. An INTP acting extroverted and social? That's their ESFJ subconscious coming out. The test didn't lie - it just told you 25% of the story.
What's the inferior function and why does it matter?

Your inferior function is your fourth cognitive function - it's where all your insecurities live. It's also the gateway to your subconscious. When someone threatens your inferior, you get instantly defensive and negative. But here's the thing - if you overcome those insecurities and develop your inferior, you unlock your subconscious willingly. That's power. Stay insecure? You get pushed into your subconscious negatively, and that's when things get ugly.
What is the nemesis function?

The nemesis is your fifth function - it's where all your worry lives. It's also the gateway to your unconscious mind. Conquer your worry and you access your unconscious willingly. Stay worried and you get forced into it negatively. For example, if you have Ni nemesis, you're constantly worried about your own future because you're too busy focusing on everyone else's future and ignoring what you actually want.
How does the critic function work?

The critic is your sixth function - it's pure self-criticism. If you have Fi critic like INFJs and ISFJs do, you constantly feel worthless and inadequate. You're always devaluing yourself. That's why these types overcompensate by caring excessively for others - they're trying to feel valuable. But here's the upside: the critic also holds your wisdom. As you age and develop it, you transform that criticism into genuine wisdom you can offer yourself and others.
What's the trickster function?

The trickster is your seventh function - it's where you're completely unaware and easily blindsided. You have zero access to this function's awareness. If your trickster is Fi like mine, you have no moral awareness. I literally can't see moral issues on my own - I need someone with strong Fi around to show me their feelings so I can translate that into ethics through my Fe. The trickster is your blind spot, and you need other people to cover it.
What is the demon function?

The demon is your eighth and lowest function - it's where your sin nature lives. This is the darkest part of you, the gateway to your superego. When you're completely destroyed by life and can't solve your problems through ego, subconscious, or unconscious, you fall into your demon. It's your superego taking over - the parasitic persona that wants to consume your ego entirely. Think Heath Ledger's Joker - an ENTP who fell into his ESFP superego demon and became pure chaotic evil.
Is the superego completely evil?

Mostly - it's about 95% negative. The superego is destructive, chaotic, and wants to burn everything down. But there's a 5% positive aspect. Sometimes you need to burn down the entire forest so new life can grow. The superego has its use, even if it's mostly corrupted. Enlightenment isn't about avoiding your superego - it's about balancing all four sides of your mind, including that dark parasitic persona.
Can I switch between being INTP and ENTP?

No. You don't switch types. If you're an INTP and you're acting extroverted, you're not becoming an ENTP - you're accessing your ENTJ unconscious or your ESFJ subconscious. Your ego stays INTP. What changes is which side of your mind is driving. People who think they switch between types don't understand the four sides. You're always all four of your types simultaneously - the question is which one is in control at any moment.
What does it mean to be in your subconscious?

Your subconscious is the inverted version of your ego - same functions, opposite attitudes. For an INTP, that's ESFJ. You access it through your inferior function. When you're feeling insecure and someone makes you comfortable, you enter your subconscious positively - you become caring, social, helpful. But if someone pushes you deeper into insecurity, you enter it negatively - defensive, petty, hostile. Your subconscious can be your greatest strength or your worst weakness depending on how you access it.
How do I know when I'm in my unconscious mind?

You're in your unconscious when you're driven by worry or desire. For an INTP, the unconscious is ENTJ. If you overcome your worries through your nemesis function, you access it willingly - you become decisive, commanding, action-oriented. But if external pressure forces you to want something you don't actually desire, you enter it negatively - you become tyrannical, controlling, destructive. The unconscious is about what you want and fear wanting.
What's the difference between hero and parent functions?

Your hero is your dominant function - it's your conscious awareness, who you truly are. It's always on, always driving. Your parent is your auxiliary function - it's responsible, protective, and nurturing. The hero explores and experiences. The parent takes care of business and protects what matters. If your hero is Ti like an INTP, you're constantly analyzing and verifying truth. Your parent Si makes you responsible about duty and past experience. Different roles, both crucial.
Why do people hate when their inferior is threatened?

Because your inferior function is where all your insecurities live. Humans need security and comfort - it's fundamental. When someone threatens your inferior, they're attacking the most vulnerable part of you. That triggers instant defensiveness and animosity. You lose control of your subconscious and get pushed into it negatively. For an INTP with Fe inferior, questioning whether people like them is threatening their core insecurity. They'll react badly every single time.
What is enlightenment according to this framework?

Enlightenment is using all four sides of your mind in perfect balance. You've overcome your worry and insecurity. You've mastered self-discipline and self-awareness. All eight of your cognitive functions work in unity - ego, subconscious, unconscious, and even superego operating in harmony. You become a complete, well-rounded human being. That's the best version of your type. Not about becoming all 16 types - it's about mastering your four sides and achieving balance within yourself.
What's the gateway function concept?

Gateway functions are the bridges between the sides of your mind. Your inferior function is the gateway to your subconscious - overcome insecurity and you access it positively. Your nemesis function is the gateway to your unconscious - overcome worry and you enter it willingly. Your demon function is the gateway to your superego - fall into despair and suffering and you get consumed by it. These gateways determine whether you access each side positively or negatively.
How does the child function work?

Your child is your third function - it's innocent, playful, and pure. It's the part of you that experiences joy and wonder. But it's also naive and can be manipulated. When your child function is happy, you feel energized and optimistic about life. When it's hurt, you become cynical and negative. For an INTP with Si child, they need positive past experiences and sensory comfort to feel good. Hurt their Si child and they become bitter about everything.
Why can't I just ignore my superego?

Because ignoring it doesn't make it go away - it makes it stronger. Your superego is parasitic. It wants to consume your ego and become your primary persona. If you pretend it doesn't exist, you're not dealing with the suffering and pain that feeds it. Eventually life will break you down enough that you'll fall into it anyway. Better to understand it, acknowledge it exists, and maintain balance so you never fully descend into that corrupted state. You can't run from 25% of who you are.
What's the relationship between the eight cognitive functions and the four sides?

You have eight cognitive functions total in your ego and unconscious - hero, parent, child, inferior, nemesis, critic, trickster, demon. But those same eight functions appear inverted in your subconscious and superego. That's 16 total cognitive function slots across all four sides of your mind. Your hero function in ego becomes your inferior in subconscious. Your nemesis in unconscious relates to specific functions in superego. All four sides use the same eight functions but in different positions and attitudes.
How accurate are MBTI tests really?

Maybe 70-80% accurate at best, and that's if you're brutally honest with yourself. Most people aren't. Tests only measure your ego anyway - that's 25% of the answer. I tested as INTJ and INFJ for years before realizing I'm actually ENTP through studying depth psychology. Tests are a starting point, not the destination. You need to verify your type by understanding cognitive functions, all four sides of your mind, and how you actually operate. Don't trust the test. Verify it yourself.
Why do we need other people's cognitive functions?

Because you can't access all 16 types alone - you only have four sides. Other people fill in the gaps. My trickster is Fi so I have zero moral awareness. I need someone with strong Fi to show me the moral dimension I can't see. Building relationships gives you access to human cognition beyond your own four types. That's how we solve complex problems - through shared cognition. Unity with others who have different types means you can tackle anything. Alone, you're limited. Together, humans are unstoppable.
